body: Try the python script for conversion. Also some of your images might be corrupted.

Darn! I must switch to linux! :-P

My speed difference is on win7 between pre-built 20151228 and 20160223. I also tried CuDNN 4 but had no difference.

The new release (20160223) works on my Windows10 machine. Great work guys!

Side note: I also noticed (in my case substantial) performance decrease in terms of speed, but that's probably related to various other things happening.

EDIT: Btw. is it possible to use CUDNN v4? Till now I was under the impression that only v3 is supported.

The new release works on my machine as well, awesome!

I also observe that Linux is faster than Windows for quite a while, I have Linux box with GTX970 which runs around 700 images per sec something over train_cifar10, but in my company's Windows machine it is only slightly higher than 620 img per sec. It might not be just a single-factor issue and perhaps we can improve it afterwards...

Interesting. I will take a look into it. I expect there to be some
performance difference between Windows and Linux, but didn't expect it to
be so huge.

Here is my results:
python train_mnist.py:

```
GTX980, Windows 10:               20000 samples/sec
Titan, Ubuntu 14.04:                  40000 samples/sec
```

Also, CPU runs much faster in this case, at around 50000 samples/sec.

python train_cifa10.py:

```
GTX980, Windows 10:               396 samples/sec
Titan, Ubuntu 14.04:                  445 samples/sec
```

So my guess is that Windows has higher overhead with regard to small GPU operations. In MNIST, the computation is so light that this overhead dominates, and thus CPU > GPU-Linux > GPU-Windows. In Cifa10, there are much less operations and hence the difference is much smaller. Has anyone tried running heavier workloads like ImageNet?

@mli   @piiswrong  could you  give me some suggestions?
@rohit12 I was hoping to take up this issue.

We have a bucketing API that is flexible for handling complicated over-time models. But we need more examples on this. So if you could help create more RNN examples with this, that could be helpful.

On the other hand, we will need to have back-propagate-through-time implementation that saves memory, that use a Python for loop to carry the computation and state-copying. This is still need to be done, and is needed for scenarios where RNNs architectures are simple but the sequences in the data might be too long to unroll.
I vote for the first choice. However, I am thinking about wrap `indptr`, `indices` and `values` into CSR matrix directly, and make transparent convert to `scipy.csr`
@antinucleon ＃1 doesn't work for large vocabulary unless we support row sparse (or indexslices) tensors.
+1 Looking forward to more RNN examples based on bucketing API

#!/usr/bin/env python
import mxnet as mx

prefix = "Inception/Inception_BN"
num_round = 39
model = mx.model.FeedForward.load(prefix, num_round, ctx=mx.gpu(), numpy_batch_size=1)

@pluskid I am familiar with backpropagation through time. I guess I could implement. Also what sort of RNN examples are you looking for? I am familiar with the common example of text generation. I could probably modify it to suit the bucketing API with a bit of help.
The thing is, I am looking at this through a GSoC perspective and I need to show a bug fix to the R org admins before I can apply for improving mxnet.

@shangjingbo1226 Any non-trivial RNN example should be fine. Just keep in mind that we already have a ptb text generation RNN example [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/rnn). And there is also one version of it adapted to bucketing API in the same folder.

Implementing BPTT involves some interface designing and thinking about how to let recurrent nodes interact with non-recurrent nodes nicely. We have some preliminary design document. We can share you this or make the doc public when you decided to work on this (e.g. via GSoC).

We have around 300M features but each sample has only around 300 non-zeros.
If batch size is small, dense weight and dense gradient will be wasteful.

@alirezabagheri There is an easier way of doing it. locals() is already added to batchparam. It captures all the local variables from _train_multi_device. You can add it to epoch_end_callback call and access everything from there.

You can do it by adding an extra aux variable to the loss layer that holds the scales.
Would you like to propose a PR?

Even with the latest code, not sure if your suggestion would exactly be easier. If the framework supported an **eval_**epoch_end_callback with argument for locals(); then that would be the best in the sense that everything could be done in the supplied callback function.
I confirm the solution worked. If not, try a larger number, like 35 seconds.

For who passed by
1. Read the neural network chapter in ESL if you haven't.
2. Search quora for related questions, and follow the answer.
3. Read tutorials in the image classification folder carefully. (The kaggle one is also helpful)
4. Skip the `prediction in pretrained`.
5. Read docs on data IO, if you haven't.

I still got a little confused about how this asyncing engine works. For example, if I just want to do forward , backward and update the arguments without getting the output and calculating the accuracy etc. Like this:

```
executor = net.simple_bind(...)
data in dataIter:
    executor.arg_dict['data'][:] = mx.nd.array(...)
    executor.arg_dict['label'][:] = mx.nd.array(...)
    executor.forward(is_train=True)
    executor.backard()
    for key in update_dict:
        updater(...)
    #dont take the output and update the metric.
```

The above code is what I mean. In this case, would it cause any problem? Since I found this could make the training much faster if I remove the updating metric, I am wondering if I could do this without messing up the training. @tqchen @piiswrong

Yes, this is totally valid. However, this may not necessarily mean training is faster. Because no synchronization with engine is made, the timer metric only means these async calls are issued, but not necessarily finished. Having the metric update enforce the synchronization, so the timer metric is more reasonable

In my case, I do image segmentation using fully convolutional networks. For the memory reasons, I use batch size 1. I found if I calculate the accuracy after every batch, It would take 2s for each sample. However, if I remove the metric updating part and just forward, backward and update, it would increase the speed to 0.5s for each sample. It could make a big difference. so that is why I asked this question. It seems waiting for the engine to get synchronized takes too much time. Does it make sense?

I think we need to be a bit careful about this. It depends on availability of stdint.
The original idea is to only use mx_uint and mx_ulong for parameter passing. Maybe consider change the uint64_t type to these types are more approperiate

So I added a BlockGrad but now c_exec.grad_arrays just contains all 0 values. Do you have an example of how to use it?

``` python
import mxnet as mx
import cmath
import numpy as np

w0 = mx.symbol.Variable('w0')
x0 = mx.symbol.Variable('x0')
w1 = mx.symbol.Variable('w1')
x1 = mx.symbol.Variable('x1')
w2 = mx.symbol.Variable('w2')

a = mx.symbol.BlockGrad(-1*(w0*x0 + w1*x1 + w2))

net = 1/(1 + (mx.symbol.pow(cmath.e, a)))

args={'w0': mx.nd.ones(1) * 2.0, 
     'x0': mx.nd.ones(1) * -1.0,
     'w1': mx.nd.ones(1) * -3.0, 
     'x1': mx.nd.ones(1) * -2.0,
     'w2': mx.nd.ones(1) * -3.0}
data_shape = (1,)

focus = net
c_exec = focus.simple_bind(ctx=mx.cpu(),
                             w0 = data_shape, 
                             x0 = data_shape,
                             w1 = data_shape, 
                             x1 = data_shape,
                             w2 = data_shape,
                          grad_req='write')


c_exec.copy_params_from(arg_params = args)

c_exec.forward()
c_exec.backward(out_grads=mx.nd.ones(1)*1)

args_dict = dict(zip(args,[o.asnumpy()[0] for o in c_exec.arg_arrays]))
outputs_dict = dict(zip(focus.list_outputs(),[o.asnumpy()[0] for o in c_exec.outputs]))
grads_dict = dict(zip([n for n in args],[o.asnumpy()[0] for o in c_exec.grad_arrays]))

print "Args   : " + str(["%s=%.2f" %(n,o) for n,o in args_dict.iteritems()])
print "Outputs: " + str(["%s=%.2f" %(n,o) for n,o in outputs_dict.iteritems()])
print "Grads  : " + str(["%s=%.2f" %(n,o) for n,o in grads_dict.iteritems()])
```

```
Args   : ['x0=2.00', 'x1=-1.00', 'w2=-3.00', 'w1=-2.00', 'w0=-3.00']
Outputs: ['_divscalar2_output=0.73']
Grads  : ['x0=0.00', 'x1=-0.00', 'w2=0.00', 'w1=0.00', 'w0=-0.00']
```

the reason that different local runs have difference results are due to
1. random data crop, weight inited with random seed
2. cudnn give random results each time

local and device are quite difference is possibly due to weight initiazation. local is inited on cpu (by glibc library), while devcie is inited on gpu (by cuda)
the difference should be much smaller if you run more epochs.

I have found the cause of the problem. Since I had make grad divided by batchsize in SoftmaxOutput operator, so if concating the hidden output for time T, the SoftmaxOutput grad will reduce to grad/T because of batchsize multiplied by T. Now everything is going well after fixed the problem.
